KH.content: speculative dialectics inscribes mythic thought in a teleological perspective
KH.linkedContent: speculative dialectics inscribes mythic thought in a teleological perspective

KH.content: mytheme, acc. Hegel, will have been a prephilosopheme promised to a dialectical Aufhebung > teleological future anterior resembles narrative while marking end of narrative fiction
KH.linkedContent: mytheme, acc. Hegel, will have been a prephilosopheme promised to a dialectical Aufhebung > teleological future anterior resembles narrative while marking end of narrative fiction

KH.content: khōra as myth w/in myth, inscribed for a moment, while having a bearing on the place of inscription, oneiric, bastard reading, heterogenous to philosopho-mytheme which orders myth to its philosophical telos
KH.linkedContent: khōra as myth w/in myth, inscribed for a moment, while having a bearing on the place of inscription, oneiric, bastard reading, heterogenous to philosopho-mytheme which orders myth to its philosophical telos

R.content: regulative Idea of Kant, a last resort, an alibi, w/ a certain dignity, can’t deny I might one day give in to it > infinite deferral or teleological vs. im-possible
R.linkedContent: regulative Idea of Kant, a last resort, an alibi, w/ a certain dignity, can’t deny I might one day give in to it > infinite deferral or teleological vs. im-possible

BL.content: Kant: typology, symbolic presentation of moral good (beauty, a symbol of morality), respect for law which only appears in law > “as if” in maxim: reconciles practical reason w/ historical teleology (narrative), w/ possibility of unlimited progress
BL.linkedContent: Kant: typology, symbolic presentation of moral good (beauty, a symbol of morality), respect for law which only appears in law > “as if” in maxim: reconciles practical reason w/ historical teleology (narrative), w/ possibility of unlimited progress

LOBL.content: [literary] title is not its own telos, not self-mirroring, writing prevents reflecting representation from folding back on itself
LOBL.linkedContent: [literary] title is not its own telos, not self-mirroring, writing prevents reflecting representation from folding back on itself

OOG.content: Husserl’s Rückfrage (return inquiry, question en retour) has a postal reference, return inquiry asked on basis of a first posting, already readable document offering possibility to ask about final intention, which is mediacy itself, openness to a general telecommunication
OOG.linkedContent: Husserl’s Rückfrage (return inquiry, question en retour) has a postal reference, return inquiry asked on basis of a first posting, already readable document offering possibility to ask about final intention, which is mediacy itself, openness to a general telecommunication

OOG.content: the way an outdated proposition remains unified & animated by intention of truth, authenticity, clarity (synonyms for Husserl) > absurd intention, “nonsense,” “countersense” continually points toward telos, owns up to telos in order to disown it (Stranger of Sophist)
OOG.linkedContent: the way an outdated proposition remains unified & animated by intention of truth, authenticity, clarity (synonyms for Husserl) > absurd intention, “nonsense,” “countersense” continually points toward telos, owns up to telos in order to disown it (Stranger of Sophist)

OOG.content: Europe is the good example of historicity, incarnating in its purity the Telos of all historicity: universality, omnitemporality, infinite traditonality
OOG.linkedContent: Europe is the good example of historicity, incarnating in its purity the Telos of all historicity: universality, omnitemporality, infinite traditonality

OOG.content: “the Absolute of the Idea as the Telos of an infinite determinability is the Absolute of intentional historicity”
OOG.linkedContent: “the Absolute of the Idea as the Telos of an infinite determinability is the Absolute of intentional historicity”

OOG.content: this “of” is neither objective nor subjective genitive > it concerns the Absolute of genitivity, the pure possibility of genetic relations, primoridal interdependence of subject/object
OOG.linkedContent: this “of” is neither objective nor subjective genitive > it concerns the Absolute of genitivity, the pure possibility of genetic relations, primoridal interdependence of subject/object

OOG.content: Logos (always has form of a Telos) is not the real transcendence but the ideal Pole for bringing about transcendental subjectivity itself
OOG.linkedContent: Logos (always has form of a Telos) is not the real transcendence but the ideal Pole for bringing about transcendental subjectivity itself

OOG.content: for Husserl, there’s nothing outside pure historicity of passage of Speech, “Logos and the Telos are nothing outside the interplay (Wechselspiel) of their reciprocal inspiration” > Absoulte is Passage
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl, there’s nothing outside pure historicity of passage of Speech, “Logos and the Telos are nothing outside the interplay (Wechselspiel) of their reciprocal inspiration” > Absoulte is Passage

SPOM.content: messianic extremity, eskhaton, exceeds, at each moment, final term of a phusis, such as work, production, and telos of any history
SPOM.linkedContent: messianic extremity, eskhaton, exceeds, at each moment, final term of a phusis, such as work, production, and telos of any history

SPOM.content: “world is going badly (le monde va mal),” il est usé mais son usure ne compte plus, vieillesse ou jeunesse [see SW pp. 322-23]—on ne compte plus avec elle, on ne s’en rend plus compte comme d’un seau âge dans le progrès d’une histoire > ce qui arrive arrive à l’âge même > messes w/ “teleological order of history”
SPOM.linkedContent: “world is going badly (le monde va mal),” il est usé mais son usure ne compte plus, vieillesse ou jeunesse [see SW pp. 322-23]—on ne compte plus avec elle, on ne s’en rend plus compte comme d’un seau âge dans le progrès d’une histoire > ce qui arrive arrive à l’âge même > messes w/ “teleological order of history”

POOF.content: friendship is political if political comes down to creating the most friendships (Eudemian Ethics 1234b 22-3, Book III of Aristotle’s Politics), the good life as philía, as télos of pólis
POOF.linkedContent: friendship is political if political comes down to creating the most friendships (Eudemian Ethics 1234b 22-3, Book III of Aristotle’s Politics), the good life as philía, as télos of pólis

POOF.content: via Aristotle’s prótē philía as teleía philía, telos of friendship as that which can’t be reached, inconceivable, self-contradictory, would be the desire for a perfect friend, for a friendship w/ God [Derrida offers 3 reasons why this is impossible]
POOF.linkedContent: via Aristotle’s prótē philía as teleía philía, telos of friendship as that which can’t be reached, inconceivable, self-contradictory, would be the desire for a perfect friend, for a friendship w/ God [Derrida offers 3 reasons why this is impossible]

POOF.content: if man has friends, it’s because he thinks the other, thought of the other as thought of the mortal, and thus there is only thought in friendship > “O my friends…” the declaration of God, who knows only divine friendship
POOF.linkedContent: if man has friends, it’s because he thinks the other, thought of the other as thought of the mortal, and thus there is only thought in friendship > “O my friends…” the declaration of God, who knows only divine friendship

POOF.content: for Zarathustra, humanity in default of an end also defaults itself (manque la fin se manque aussi elle-même) —is itself en manque d’humanité
POOF.linkedContent: for Zarathustra, humanity in default of an end also defaults itself (manque la fin se manque aussi elle-même) —is itself en manque d’humanité

A.content: pas [belongs to French?] involves the line that terminates all determination, peras (end, limit) not telos, puts us on path beyond, on other side, peraō eis khoran (penetrate into place, country)
A.linkedContent: pas [belongs to French?] involves the line that terminates all determination, peras (end, limit) not telos, puts us on path beyond, on other side, peraō eis khoran (penetrate into place, country)

A.content: Heidegger distinguishes death of Dasein from its end (Ende), from its maturation or ripeness (Reife), Dasein don’t need to mature when death occurs, not a final maturity, not an limit end, a telos, terma, a border > Dasein is very transgression of this borderline
A.linkedContent: Heidegger distinguishes death of Dasein from its end (Ende), from its maturation or ripeness (Reife), Dasein don’t need to mature when death occurs, not a final maturity, not an limit end, a telos, terma, a border > Dasein is very transgression of this borderline

A.content: abyssal inquiry re: Heidegger’s delimitation of death, modes of ending, more than one limit, ends of man an indestructable subject > death of Dasein not end of man, btwn the 2 there’s a divisible limit, perhaps, of ending, place where ending ends [?]
A.linkedContent: abyssal inquiry re: Heidegger’s delimitation of death, modes of ending, more than one limit, ends of man an indestructable subject > death of Dasein not end of man, btwn the 2 there’s a divisible limit, perhaps, of ending, place where ending ends [?]

A.content: absolute arrivant, no more commands than commanded by memory of originary event where archaic is bound to final extremity (telos, eskhaton)
A.linkedContent: absolute arrivant, no more commands than commanded by memory of originary event where archaic is bound to final extremity (telos, eskhaton)

A.content: double sense of de-termination [re: determined closure]: logic of termination (terma, peras, finis) and resolute decision or resolution [Being in Time great discourse on Entschlossenheit]
A.linkedContent: double sense of de-termination [re: determined closure]: logic of termination (terma, peras, finis) and resolute decision or resolution [Being in Time great discourse on Entschlossenheit]

EM.content: “la relève ou la relevance de l’homme est son télos ou son eskhaton” (p. (147) 2 ends)
EM.linkedContent: “la relève ou la relevance de l’homme est son télos ou son eskhaton” (p. (147) 2 ends)

EM.content: truth of man, metaphysics, always has an ends of man
EM.linkedContent: truth of man, metaphysics, always has an ends of man

EM.content: is there an ends of man w/out teleology of nous?
EM.linkedContent: is there an ends of man w/out teleology of nous?

EM.content: Kant’s pure end of moral law—not anthropological
EM.linkedContent: Kant’s pure end of moral law—not anthropological

EM.content: thinking of appearance (phainesthai) linked to thinking of telos
EM.linkedContent: thinking of appearance (phainesthai) linked to thinking of telos

EM.content: man’s specificity, as rational animal, announces itself to itself, as an infinite end
EM.linkedContent: man’s specificity, as rational animal, announces itself to itself, as an infinite end

EM.content: prescription of the end of man, prescribed since always, has done nothing but “modulate equivocality of the end, in the play of telos and death”
EM.linkedContent: prescription of the end of man, prescribed since always, has done nothing but “modulate equivocality of the end, in the play of telos and death”

EM.content: dans la lecture de ce jeu: le fin de l’homme est la pensée de l’être, l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être, la fin de l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être > l’homme est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-a-dire la fin de son propre > l’être est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-à-dire la fin de son propre
EM.linkedContent: dans la lecture de ce jeu: le fin de l’homme est la pensée de l’être, l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être, la fin de l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être > l’homme est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-a-dire la fin de son propre > l’être est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-à-dire la fin de son propre

SEC.content: general possibility of “parasite”: 1) trap (piège), failure (échec), abyss outside/in front of language, ditch (fossé), place of external perdition, which language can avoid, sheltered by (à l’abri de) its essence or telos? 2) or is this risk, internal and positive condition of its possibility, this outside its inside?
SEC.linkedContent: general possibility of “parasite”: 1) trap (piège), failure (échec), abyss outside/in front of language, ditch (fossé), place of external perdition, which language can avoid, sheltered by (à l’abri de) its essence or telos? 2) or is this risk, internal and positive condition of its possibility, this outside its inside?

SEC.content: Austin makes us accept as ordinary a teleological and ethical determination > univocality of statement, self presence of total context, transparency of intentions, presence of meaning—absolute singular oneness of speech act
SEC.linkedContent: Austin makes us accept as ordinary a teleological and ethical determination > univocality of statement, self presence of total context, transparency of intentions, presence of meaning—absolute singular oneness of speech act

OH.content: “cap” (caput, capitis), the head, extremity of the extreme, last legs, final moment (eschaton > telos); captain (not a woman); eschatology and teleology—that is man
OH.linkedContent: “cap” (caput, capitis), the head, extremity of the extreme, last legs, final moment (eschaton > telos); captain (not a woman); eschatology and teleology—that is man

OH.content: in the dated nature of dating, of currentness, lies a disquieting wrinkle, stigmata of anachrony marking all our days > traditional discourse of modernity, discourse of anamnesis w/ its goût de fin, if not for death
OH.linkedContent: in the dated nature of dating, of currentness, lies a disquieting wrinkle, stigmata of anachrony marking all our days > traditional discourse of modernity, discourse of anamnesis w/ its goût de fin, if not for death

OH.content: horizon (ancient Greek) = limit; to see itself (Europe) on the horizon, is to see itself from its end, discourse of anamnesis—taste for finality (goût de fin), for death
OH.linkedContent: horizon (ancient Greek) = limit; to see itself (Europe) on the horizon, is to see itself from its end, discourse of anamnesis—taste for finality (goût de fin), for death

VP.content: Husserl determines logos on basis of logic, giving logicity the normalcy of logos’ telos, the telos of being as presence; this requires distinction btwn pure logic or “pure logical grammar” and pure grammar [logic before language]
VP.linkedContent: Husserl determines logos on basis of logic, giving logicity the normalcy of logos’ telos, the telos of being as presence; this requires distinction btwn pure logic or “pure logical grammar” and pure grammar [logic before language]

VP.content: dignity of a telos, purity of a norm, essence of a destination
VP.linkedContent: dignity of a telos, purity of a norm, essence of a destination

VP.content: every time presence is threatened Husserl appeals to a telos, Idea in the Kantian sense, infinity of prescribed progress, permitted repetition
VP.linkedContent: every time presence is threatened Husserl appeals to a telos, Idea in the Kantian sense, infinity of prescribed progress, permitted repetition

VP.content: knowledge as norm, intuition adequate to its object, already opened by promise, telos, in truth, the pro-visional [difference btwn intuition/intention] as essence of meaning (vouloir-dire), discourse adheres to discursive essence when false, attains its entelechy when true
VP.linkedContent: knowledge as norm, intuition adequate to its object, already opened by promise, telos, in truth, the pro-visional [difference btwn intuition/intention] as essence of meaning (vouloir-dire), discourse adheres to discursive essence when false, attains its entelechy when true

VP.content: “pure logical grammar” > le sens n’attend pas la vérité insofar as it expects it (en tant qu’il l’attend)
VP.linkedContent: “pure logical grammar” > le sens n’attend pas la vérité insofar as it expects it (en tant qu’il l’attend)

S.content: Aristotle’s dynamis (potentiality) is a virtuality oriented by a telos
S.linkedContent: Aristotle’s dynamis (potentiality) is a virtuality oriented by a telos

PPHS.content: for Derrida, contents of semiology cannot be exhausted by the metaphysical theory which regulates bedeuten (meaning) by the telos of speech
PPHS.linkedContent: for Derrida, contents of semiology cannot be exhausted by the metaphysical theory which regulates bedeuten (meaning) by the telos of speech

PPHS.content: sensory matter hierarchized acc. power of ideality; physical ideality as teleological anticipation, or inversely, concept and value of ideality a “metaphor” > the “history” of metaphysics; sensualist reduction & idealist teleology follow same line [circle]: “metaphor”
PPHS.linkedContent: sensory matter hierarchized acc. power of ideality; physical ideality as teleological anticipation, or inversely, concept and value of ideality a “metaphor” > the “history” of metaphysics; sensualist reduction & idealist teleology follow same line [circle]: “metaphor”

WM.content: via Aristotle, univocity (one meaning per noun) is telos (essence) of language, there is only finite polysemia: a nonmasterable dissemination (an irreducible polysemia) is not even a polysemia, it belongs to what is outside language, and thus outside humanity
WM.linkedContent: via Aristotle, univocity (one meaning per noun) is telos (essence) of language, there is only finite polysemia: a nonmasterable dissemination (an irreducible polysemia) is not even a polysemia, it belongs to what is outside language, and thus outside humanity

OS.content: for Aristotle, potentiality & act are not symmetrical: governed by teleology of presence, act (energeia) as presence (ousia, parousia)
OS.linkedContent: for Aristotle, potentiality & act are not symmetrical: governed by teleology of presence, act (energeia) as presence (ousia, parousia)

P.content: for Hegel, telos of beauty is found in art not nature; for Hegel, there’s almost no natural beauty, and it is inferior to beauty produced by mind
P.linkedContent: for Hegel, telos of beauty is found in art not nature; for Hegel, there’s almost no natural beauty, and it is inferior to beauty produced by mind

P.content: but en blanc [cf. C p. 229 can(n)on] (gun as finality w/out end in sight) [goal as white page] Kant’s finality w/out end: free beauty, wild tulip
P.linkedContent: but en blanc [cf. C p. 229 can(n)on] (gun as finality w/out end in sight) [goal as white page] Kant’s finality w/out end: free beauty, wild tulip

P.content: free beauty, tulip, cut off from fecundation but not sterile: sterility is determined from the end (as end of end)
P.linkedContent: free beauty, tulip, cut off from fecundation but not sterile: sterility is determined from the end (as end of end)

P.content: adherent/vague beauty cannot relate—is there a frame btwn them? suspending relation, puts them in relation > which is the example of which?
P.linkedContent: adherent/vague beauty cannot relate—is there a frame btwn them? suspending relation, puts them in relation > which is the example of which?

P.content: pure telos of beauty (as non-telos), telos of 2 beauties would be sans, nonpresentation of telos
P.linkedContent: pure telos of beauty (as non-telos), telos of 2 beauties would be sans, nonpresentation of telos

P.content: conceptual determination of end limits free play (of imagination): sans opens play w/in beauty
P.linkedContent: conceptual determination of end limits free play (of imagination): sans opens play w/in beauty

P.content: one must choose btwn not seeing beauty & seeing the end
P.linkedContent: one must choose btwn not seeing beauty & seeing the end

P.content: the strange fact that the median propositions (those on free beauty) in Kant’s Critique remain suspended, lack immediate justification—though magnetized by their end
P.linkedContent: the strange fact that the median propositions (those on free beauty) in Kant’s Critique remain suspended, lack immediate justification—though magnetized by their end

P.content: perfection [teleological end, purpose] often confused w/ beauty, Kant breaks from this tradition > judgment of taste does not bear on perfection of object, its internal possibility of existence—those examples (man, horse, buildings) which only have adherent beauty always have relation to man [Kant’s beauty as anti-anthropological in its anti-perfection] [the subjective finality or finality w/out end (beauty) vs. objective finality]
P.linkedContent: perfection [teleological end, purpose] often confused w/ beauty, Kant breaks from this tradition > judgment of taste does not bear on perfection of object, its internal possibility of existence—those examples (man, horse, buildings) which only have adherent beauty always have relation to man [Kant’s beauty as anti-anthropological in its anti-perfection] [the subjective finality or finality w/out end (beauty) vs. objective finality]

P.content: the horse is so much a part of man’s telos, it can never achieve errant, free beauty, unable to disregard its objective finality which can only be external
P.linkedContent: the horse is so much a part of man’s telos, it can never achieve errant, free beauty, unable to disregard its objective finality which can only be external

P.content: acc. Kant, though we cannot determine empirical laws of nature, we must act as if an understanding (not our own) gave them unity [regulative idea?]
P.linkedContent: acc. Kant, though we cannot determine empirical laws of nature, we must act as if an understanding (not our own) gave them unity [regulative idea?]

P.content: in Kant, art of man analogized with art of creator (unity of empirical laws), man has goal before operating, this effaces a priori the sans, the pure cut of free beauty
P.linkedContent: in Kant, art of man analogized with art of creator (unity of empirical laws), man has goal before operating, this effaces a priori the sans, the pure cut of free beauty

P.content: connection btwn anthropo-theologism & analogism: course being steered [Spinoza says something quite tangential in Ethics], analogy w/ practical finality is its medium
P.linkedContent: connection btwn anthropo-theologism & analogism: course being steered [Spinoza says something quite tangential in Ethics], analogy w/ practical finality is its medium

P.content: analogism saturates hiatus by repetition: mise en abyme resists the abyss of collapse, reconstitutes economy of mimesis (economimesis), l’analogisme recapitule ou recapite
P.linkedContent: analogism saturates hiatus by repetition: mise en abyme resists the abyss of collapse, reconstitutes economy of mimesis (economimesis), l’analogisme recapitule ou recapite

P.content: an object is “prodigious,” monstrous (not colossal), when, by size, it annihilates & reduces to nothing the end which constitutes its concept, exceeds the final limit, overflows end & concept
P.linkedContent: an object is “prodigious,” monstrous (not colossal), when, by size, it annihilates & reduces to nothing the end which constitutes its concept, exceeds the final limit, overflows end & concept

ATIA.content: for Kant [via Adorno], animals have no teleology (so always a means), they have no dignity (Würde), that is, no priceless internal value, so always a price, always belong to sensible world that must be sacrificed; Adorno sees in this a hatred towards animals, a Kant avec Sade
ATIA.linkedContent: for Kant [via Adorno], animals have no teleology (so always a means), they have no dignity (Würde), that is, no priceless internal value, so always a price, always belong to sensible world that must be sacrificed; Adorno sees in this a hatred towards animals, a Kant avec Sade

ATIA.content: Kant’s providential-machine (Maschinenwesen der Vorsehung), which teleologizes in advance all war machines, would prosecute war w/out mercy against animal in form pax humana
ATIA.linkedContent: Kant’s providential-machine (Maschinenwesen der Vorsehung), which teleologizes in advance all war machines, would prosecute war w/out mercy against animal in form pax humana

GSP.content: how “untamed genesis” demanded of Husserl a metaphysics of history and a solid structure of telos, moving phenomenology beyond descriptive space, beyond phenomenology?
GSP.linkedContent: how “untamed genesis” demanded of Husserl a metaphysics of history and a solid structure of telos, moving phenomenology beyond descriptive space, beyond phenomenology?

GSP.content: genetic description of ego prescribes task of a universal genetic phenomenology (a eidos of historicity) for Husserl, this is not a series of ruptures, revolutions, that tear open a previous finitude to lay bear a hidden infinity, giving voice to dynamis of silence > the ruptures are always already indicated [Telos] [Derrida wonders if this a metaphysical affirmation in a phenemonology]
GSP.linkedContent: genetic description of ego prescribes task of a universal genetic phenomenology (a eidos of historicity) for Husserl, this is not a series of ruptures, revolutions, that tear open a previous finitude to lay bear a hidden infinity, giving voice to dynamis of silence > the ruptures are always already indicated [Telos] [Derrida wonders if this a metaphysical affirmation in a phenemonology]

GSP.content: Telos/Vorhaben > infinite theoretical anticipation & infinite practical task: Kantian Idea as project of phenom.? makes it possible by overflowing its system (as its end?) > doesn’t enclose genesis of Being & meaning—is structurally genesis itself: origin/becoming, birth of history
GSP.linkedContent: Telos/Vorhaben > infinite theoretical anticipation & infinite practical task: Kantian Idea as project of phenom.? makes it possible by overflowing its system (as its end?) > doesn’t enclose genesis of Being & meaning—is structurally genesis itself: origin/becoming, birth of history

FS.content: Proust’s aesthetic/critical method not outside the work, but heart of its creation > the end of the book engenders its beginning (Derrida compares Proust to Hegel)
FS.linkedContent: Proust’s aesthetic/critical method not outside the work, but heart of its creation > the end of the book engenders its beginning (Derrida compares Proust to Hegel)

FS.content: logos spermatikos: adult in miniature, encasement, anthropomorphic concept, preformationsim, biological idea, totality of hereditary characteristics enveloped in germ
FS.linkedContent: logos spermatikos: adult in miniature, encasement, anthropomorphic concept, preformationsim, biological idea, totality of hereditary characteristics enveloped in germ

FS.content: structuralism tries to avoid all finalism, telos, tries not to refuse every accident as an aberration, but it lives w/in, on, its promise & practice: how can there be an organized totality w/out end, or intentionality w/out consciousness?
FS.linkedContent: structuralism tries to avoid all finalism, telos, tries not to refuse every accident as an aberration, but it lives w/in, on, its promise & practice: how can there be an organized totality w/out end, or intentionality w/out consciousness?

FS.content: structuralist totality promises infidelity to telos, but: structures must permit totality to open, overflow itself, totality thus takes on meaning by anticipating telos > an opening which liberates genesis and time but risks stifling force under futural becoming of teleological form
FS.linkedContent: structuralist totality promises infidelity to telos, but: structures must permit totality to open, overflow itself, totality thus takes on meaning by anticipating telos > an opening which liberates genesis and time but risks stifling force under futural becoming of teleological form

O.content: absolute knowledge present at 0 point of philosophical exposition: saturate text w/ meaning (sens), teleologically equate it [the text?] w/ its (sa) conceptual tenor
O.linkedContent: absolute knowledge present at 0 point of philosophical exposition: saturate text w/ meaning (sens), teleologically equate it [the text?] w/ its (sa) conceptual tenor

O.content: the 2 fictions: 1) when fiction is in service of meaning, truth is (truth of) fiction, it is low on a hierarchy, accessory to concept 2) fiction outside mimetologism affirms itself as simulacrum, disorganizes all oppositions to which teleology of book sought to violently subordinate it
O.linkedContent: the 2 fictions: 1) when fiction is in service of meaning, truth is (truth of) fiction, it is low on a hierarchy, accessory to concept 2) fiction outside mimetologism affirms itself as simulacrum, disorganizes all oppositions to which teleology of book sought to violently subordinate it

DPi.content: for Hugo, seed of abolition (germe always goes together w/ teleology), abolition will happen, a magnificent advance, advance is credit: make civilization a loan in advance > promise
DPi.linkedContent: for Hugo, seed of abolition (germe always goes together w/ teleology), abolition will happen, a magnificent advance, advance is credit: make civilization a loan in advance > promise

DPi.content: spirit of revolution makes an advance to spirit of civilization
DPi.linkedContent: spirit of revolution makes an advance to spirit of civilization

DPi.content: an end will never put an end to finitude because: finality of this end will produce phantasm of this end of finitude, the other side of an infinitization (experience constitutive of finitude)
DPi.linkedContent: an end will never put an end to finitude because: finality of this end will produce phantasm of this end of finitude, the other side of an infinitization (experience constitutive of finitude)

Gii.content: for Fichte, “we” of Geschlecht, question of humanity (Menschlichkeit) (versus animality) > teleological essence of humanity announced par excellence in Deutschheit
Gii.linkedContent: for Fichte, “we” of Geschlecht, question of humanity (Menschlichkeit) (versus animality) > teleological essence of humanity announced par excellence in Deutschheit

PIO.content: both Descartes & Leibniz demonstrate 2 meanings of word “invention” in phrase “invention of truth”—when pursuing a universal language: both speak of a universal characteristic, both think about a new machinery to be forged and found
PIO.linkedContent: both Descartes & Leibniz demonstrate 2 meanings of word “invention” in phrase “invention of truth”—when pursuing a universal language: both speak of a universal characteristic, both think about a new machinery to be forged and found

PIO.content: Leibniz, however, believes the invention of this language does not depend on human perfection of “true philosophy,” the language itself can lead us towards such perfection, the invention thus preceding knowledge/science, until, at last: to reason = to calculate
PIO.linkedContent: Leibniz, however, believes the invention of this language does not depend on human perfection of “true philosophy,” the language itself can lead us towards such perfection, the invention thus preceding knowledge/science, until, at last: to reason = to calculate

PIO.content: Leibniz’s version of universal language confers productive facilitation, even if inaugural adventure is kept under teleological surveillance by fundamental analyticism
PIO.linkedContent: Leibniz’s version of universal language confers productive facilitation, even if inaugural adventure is kept under teleological surveillance by fundamental analyticism

AFR.content: Condillac’s move from perception to imagination (and from one sign to another): on the march toward freedom, spontaneity of auto-affection > teleology: the complete sign, the true sign, is the instituted sign [after rupture, process magnetized toward greatest mastery possible]
AFR.linkedContent: Condillac’s move from perception to imagination (and from one sign to another): on the march toward freedom, spontaneity of auto-affection > teleology: the complete sign, the true sign, is the instituted sign [after rupture, process magnetized toward greatest mastery possible]

AFR.content: frivolity originates from deviation or gap of signifier, also from its folding back on itself in closed, nonrepresentative identity
AFR.linkedContent: frivolity originates from deviation or gap of signifier, also from its folding back on itself in closed, nonrepresentative identity

AFR.content: we escape frivolity only at semantic risk of nonidentity; Condillac names nonidentity metaphor, makes it the primordial structure of language to begin its analogical/teleological reappropriation
AFR.linkedContent: we escape frivolity only at semantic risk of nonidentity; Condillac names nonidentity metaphor, makes it the primordial structure of language to begin its analogical/teleological reappropriation

AFR.content: via Condillac, desire no longer a direction, but an end w/out end > moment stone (statue) comes to life, works to reduce gap, (not) become dead again—contrary to frivolous distraction, to headstrong identity of signs: fear of Medusa [fear of frivolous?], legitimacy itself
AFR.linkedContent: via Condillac, desire no longer a direction, but an end w/out end > moment stone (statue) comes to life, works to reduce gap, (not) become dead again—contrary to frivolous distraction, to headstrong identity of signs: fear of Medusa [fear of frivolous?], legitimacy itself

EL.content: secularize (desacralize): remove point, sting (Stachel), apocalyptic thorn of language > sting, this teleological aim (visée), institutes sacredness of language > this sacred language (Hebrew) would be nothing w/out magnetized pointer of apocalypse (cette pointe aimantée d’apocalypse)
EL.linkedContent: secularize (desacralize): remove point, sting (Stachel), apocalyptic thorn of language > sting, this teleological aim (visée), institutes sacredness of language > this sacred language (Hebrew) would be nothing w/out magnetized pointer of apocalypse (cette pointe aimantée d’apocalypse)

LI.content: Derrida does not impose a clean break w/ intention but calls into question its telos, its fulfillment, its actualization in a plenitude that would be present to & identical w/ itself
LI.linkedContent: Derrida does not impose a clean break w/ intention but calls into question its telos, its fulfillment, its actualization in a plenitude that would be present to & identical w/ itself

LI.content: intention is differing/deferring in its inception
LI.linkedContent: intention is differing/deferring in its inception

LI.content: telos of “fulfillment” (in this I believe Husserl was right) is not accidental, separable from concept of intentionality—conditions it [cf. p. 56 is there disingenuousness here?]
LI.linkedContent: telos of “fulfillment” (in this I believe Husserl was right) is not accidental, separable from concept of intentionality—conditions it [cf. p. 56 is there disingenuousness here?]

LI.content: this telos, a “longing for metaphysical plenitude,” can be lived/described w/out romantic, even mystical pathos sometimes associated w/ these words
LI.linkedContent: this telos, a “longing for metaphysical plenitude,” can be lived/described w/out romantic, even mystical pathos sometimes associated w/ these words

LI.content: for Searle, “realization” signifies “actualization” or “fulfillment”: “serious/literal” are exemplary qualities of idealized realization of intention, what language ought to do
LI.linkedContent: for Searle, “realization” signifies “actualization” or “fulfillment”: “serious/literal” are exemplary qualities of idealized realization of intention, what language ought to do

LI.content: plenitude is telos, but structure of this telos is such that attainment = death/paralysis > thus, telos divided/split, this non-end not an extraneous vestige but most intimate and irreducible other in intentionality; plenitude orients and endangers intention [“dispossessed of long-for presence…”]
LI.linkedContent: plenitude is telos, but structure of this telos is such that attainment = death/paralysis > thus, telos divided/split, this non-end not an extraneous vestige but most intimate and irreducible other in intentionality; plenitude orients and endangers intention [“dispossessed of long-for presence…”]

LI.content: non-end lasts wherever there’s life, language, intention, mark, finite infinite of differance
LI.linkedContent: non-end lasts wherever there’s life, language, intention, mark, finite infinite of differance

LI.content: iterability not merely a law of intentionality, though it introduces the structural limit of its telos > Derrida distrusts figure of intention, which grows increasingly obscure [Derrida not in “conflict” w/ intentionality, just observes limit to its telos > intentionality no more telos than arché]
LI.linkedContent: iterability not merely a law of intentionality, though it introduces the structural limit of its telos > Derrida distrusts figure of intention, which grows increasingly obscure [Derrida not in “conflict” w/ intentionality, just observes limit to its telos > intentionality no more telos than arché]

TN.content: aporias, never through with them (those worthy their name), can’t see or touch their end
TN.linkedContent: aporias, never through with them (those worthy their name), can’t see or touch their end

TN.content: tôt (soon): d’avance dévoré par cet autre du temps, consumed, burned, tostus refers to instant, au temps sans temps d’une flamme > on the verge, it’s the end: no time for motion, trop tard
TN.linkedContent: tôt (soon): d’avance dévoré par cet autre du temps, consumed, burned, tostus refers to instant, au temps sans temps d’une flamme > on the verge, it’s the end: no time for motion, trop tard

TN.content: for Kant, only man has hand (telos): allows us to explore form, whereas coldness, heat, softness are just “vital”
TN.linkedContent: for Kant, only man has hand (telos): allows us to explore form, whereas coldness, heat, softness are just “vital”

TN.content: desire is intuitionistic—as soon as it’s weaned (sevré) of intuition > lethal contradiction, sign of its end, its telos (telos is haptico-intuitionistic)
TN.linkedContent: desire is intuitionistic—as soon as it’s weaned (sevré) of intuition > lethal contradiction, sign of its end, its telos (telos is haptico-intuitionistic)

TN.content: self-relation, “s’efforcer” > institutes/born to itself as exertion moment when limit insists, resists > efforcement as effort/limit, a finite force s’arrête, and se replie toward itself depuis sa fin
TN.linkedContent: self-relation, “s’efforcer” > institutes/born to itself as exertion moment when limit insists, resists > efforcement as effort/limit, a finite force s’arrête, and se replie toward itself depuis sa fin

TN.content: Nancy’s technē deconstructs system of ends: always “technē of the next one (du prochain)”
TN.linkedContent: Nancy’s technē deconstructs system of ends: always “technē of the next one (du prochain)”

E.content: for Kant, the purpose-lessness (le sans-fin) of the experience of beauty leads us inside ourselves, there’s an interiorizing suppléance, a slurping (suçotement), by which we find our moral destination w/in, consume w/in what we can’t consume outside; this inside purpose, teleology, is moral and analogously relates to natural harmony
E.linkedContent: for Kant, the purpose-lessness (le sans-fin) of the experience of beauty leads us inside ourselves, there’s an interiorizing suppléance, a slurping (suçotement), by which we find our moral destination w/in, consume w/in what we can’t consume outside; this inside purpose, teleology, is moral and analogously relates to natural harmony

WOG.content: closure is not end of metaphysics, which doesn’t have a self-identity
WOG.linkedContent: closure is not end of metaphysics, which doesn’t have a self-identity

BSi.content: for Aristotle, autarkeia (self-sufficiency), sovereign, has an end in himself, is best > the end of everything
BSi.linkedContent: for Aristotle, autarkeia (self-sufficiency), sovereign, has an end in himself, is best > the end of everything

OG.content: for Saussure & Husserl, teleology of phonetic writing makes the crisis of nonphonetic writing psychological errors, these nonintutionisms exile from sense; for Husserl, unlike Saussure, empty formalism part of his teleology > dialectical use of negativity should force us to rethink crisis (crisis not a mere accident)
OG.linkedContent: for Saussure & Husserl, teleology of phonetic writing makes the crisis of nonphonetic writing psychological errors, these nonintutionisms exile from sense; for Husserl, unlike Saussure, empty formalism part of his teleology > dialectical use of negativity should force us to rethink crisis (crisis not a mere accident)

OG.content: confessions of anthropologist [does an anthropologist write anything else?], 18th century, humility before a goodness European society has lost: a “zero degree,” native soil, an eschatology/teleology of full, immediate closing of history
OG.linkedContent: confessions of anthropologist [does an anthropologist write anything else?], 18th century, humility before a goodness European society has lost: a “zero degree,” native soil, an eschatology/teleology of full, immediate closing of history

OG.content: via Rousseau, exceed nature, then return to it, imitate it, but keep a minimal (almost nil) difference > nature as ailleurs, archeo-teleologic, alibi (elsewhere in space), in illo tempore (elsewhere in time)
OG.linkedContent: via Rousseau, exceed nature, then return to it, imitate it, but keep a minimal (almost nil) difference > nature as ailleurs, archeo-teleologic, alibi (elsewhere in space), in illo tempore (elsewhere in time)

OG.content: [vis-à-vis Rousseau] in an archeoteleological concept of nature [eg. identification of word & song, avant et afin]: modification becomes one w/ substance it modifies: (nature & its other, archeology & eschatology, substance & mode, origin & genesis) > this logic wreaks havoc on juridical/methodological point of view, annuls difference btwn structural/genetic point of view
OG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Rousseau] in an archeoteleological concept of nature [eg. identification of word & song, avant et afin]: modification becomes one w/ substance it modifies: (nature & its other, archeology & eschatology, substance & mode, origin & genesis) > this logic wreaks havoc on juridical/methodological point of view, annuls difference btwn structural/genetic point of view

OG.content: natural immediacy is à la fois origine et fin, in the double sense of birth & death, unfinished sketch and finished perfection (esquisse inachevée et perfection finie) [how Rousseau’s contradiction is only apparent, how his law of concept of nature constrains natural law]
OG.linkedContent: natural immediacy is à la fois origine et fin, in the double sense of birth & death, unfinished sketch and finished perfection (esquisse inachevée et perfection finie) [how Rousseau’s contradiction is only apparent, how his law of concept of nature constrains natural law]

OG.content: [in Rousseau’s archeo-teleology] origin & end are inertia

[vis-à-vis Rousseau] teleology as external—passage from state of nature to state of language (from one structure to another) explained by catastrophic archaeology (catastrophe of dangerous supplementarity)
OG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Rousseau] teleology as external—passage from state of nature to state of language (from one structure to another) explained by catastrophic archaeology (catastrophe of dangerous supplementarity)

ATAP.content: [apocalypse w/out apocalypse] X w/out X, sans marks internal/external catastrophe of apocalypse, catastrophe of sans doesn’t merge w/ announced end, is its pli: a closure w/out end, end w/out end > outside of apocalypse w/in apocalypse
ATAP.linkedContent: [apocalypse w/out apocalypse] X w/out X, sans marks internal/external catastrophe of apocalypse, catastrophe of sans doesn’t merge w/ announced end, is its pli: a closure w/out end, end w/out end > outside of apocalypse w/in apocalypse

ATAP.content: “do not seal”: i.e. do not close, do not sign
ATAP.linkedContent: “do not seal”: i.e. do not close, do not sign

UWC.content: “as if the end of work were at the origin of the world”: begin at once at end & at beginning > begin w/ end as if it were the beginning [event or telos?]
UWC.linkedContent: “as if the end of work were at the origin of the world”: begin at once at end & at beginning > begin w/ end as if it were the beginning [event or telos?]

SPEC.content: because speculator is a motivated observer, completion could never be declared by him > also, there’s a structure of incompletion in scene of writing: unconscious binds (lie) one to other [scene described & description], telecommunicated acc. same teleology
SPEC.linkedContent: because speculator is a motivated observer, completion could never be declared by him > also, there’s a structure of incompletion in scene of writing: unconscious binds (lie) one to other [scene described & description], telecommunicated acc. same teleology

SPEC.content: what binds (lie) game to itself is re- of return, the returned or the returning (le revenu ou le revenant), revenance orders entire teleology, can be handed over to PP
SPEC.linkedContent: what binds (lie) game to itself is re- of return, the returned or the returning (le revenu ou le revenant), revenance orders entire teleology, can be handed over to PP

SPEC.content: mastery of PP [grand (-père) spéculateur] as mastery in general, Herrschaft distanced from PP only to reappropriate itself: tauto-teleology makes other return in its domestic specter
SPEC.linkedContent: mastery of PP [grand (-père) spéculateur] as mastery in general, Herrschaft distanced from PP only to reappropriate itself: tauto-teleology makes other return in its domestic specter

SPEC.content: Nirvana—death drive, teleology organizes return of old, oldest, furthest away
SPEC.linkedContent: Nirvana—death drive, teleology organizes return of old, oldest, furthest away

CHOR.content: once feminism movements reappropriate stifled past, feminism will perhaps have to renounce all too easy progressivism
CHOR.linkedContent: once feminism movements reappropriate stifled past, feminism will perhaps have to renounce all too easy progressivism

CHOR.content: “dogmatics” of feminism as telos, sinister mystification, will flounder in same homogenized, sterilized river of history of mankind [w/ its age-old dream of reappropriation]
CHOR.linkedContent: “dogmatics” of feminism as telos, sinister mystification, will flounder in same homogenized, sterilized river of history of mankind [w/ its age-old dream of reappropriation]
